awd_titl_txt: Molecular mechanisms underlying Snail2-mediated neural crest cell migration
awd_abstract_narration:
Organisms frequently direct stationary cells to become migratory in order to build various structures throughout their body.  One such migratory cell type, the neural crest, gives rise to portions of the heart, components of the gut and sensory nervous systems, skin pigment cells, and the craniofacial skeleton.  The formation of migratory neural crest cells is mediated, in part, by the activity of a protein called Snail2.  The central goal of this research project is to delineate the role of Snail2, and the genes Snail2 regulates, during neural crest cell migration. To address this question, various molecular and biochemical experiments will be performed to examine the role of two putative Snail2 target genes, alpha-N-catenin and cingulin, in the neural crest.  The results of this work will reveal the distribution and function of alpha-N-catenin and cingulin in the developing embryo, as well as define the mechanism by which Snail2 regulates alpha-N-catenin and cingulin.  

The broader impacts of this proposal include: 1) the integration of research and teaching at the high school, undergraduate, and graduate levels, 2) the support of female scientists through participation in the University of Maryland, College Park chapter of the Association for Women in Science, and 3) the generation of important reagents that will be available to the scientific community.  Collectively, this project will help better prepare the next generation of scientists for careers in both academic and non-academic settings, and the proposed experiments will shed light on the processes regulating neural crest cell migration and the fundamental molecular mechanisms controlling the directed movement of cells during embryonic development.

por.por_cntn:
The formation of a properly functioning organism is a highly dynamic process that involves the collective coordination of multiple changes at the cellular and molecular level. To this end, organisms frequently direct stationary cells to become migratory in order to build various structures throughout their body plan. This process involves a change in cell state such that a previously non-motile, epithelial cell is converted to a cell type capable of motility, a mesenchymal cell, to promote migration. This phenomenon, called an epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition (EMT), underlies a wide variety of cellular movements that occur during development in order to create cell types that will ultimately form muscle, portions of the heart, components of the gut and sensory nervous systems, pigment cells, and the craniofacial skeleton. Many of the aforementioned cell types are derived exclusively from one cell type, the neural crest. How neural crest cells undergo EMT and migrate, however, is still poorly understood. During this award period, we defined and characterized several proteins that play critical roles in controlling neural crest cell EMT, migration, and later differentiation into the cranial trigeminal ganglia, which are an important component of the sensory nervous system. Many of these proteins normally serve to hold neural crest cells together and therefore must be lost or reduced as neural crest cells proceed through EMT. Furthermore, we uncovered two different methods used by neural crest cells to control protein levels during EMT and revealed that they directly impinge upon the successful completion of EMT. Taken together, the results from this project have had immediate relevance to developmental mechanisms used by other animals and have yielded novel insights into how coordinated cell movement, in general, effectively patterns the embryo to build a functioning organism.

The broader impacts achieved during this award period included 1) the integration of research and teaching at multiple levels and 2) the support and encouragement of female scientists at the PI’s institution. This project provided research and teaching skills and experiences to the PI, three postdocs, and several graduate, undergraduate and high school students. All of the postdocs and graduate students, and many of the undergraduates, are authors in scientific publications from the PI’s lab, and all personnel attended scientific meetings in order for them to get critical feedback on their research and network within the scientific community. In addition, the PI established a journal club that includes seven labs on campus in order to encourage scientific discourse and to enhance oral presentation skills for its participants. Finally, the PI initiated a mentoring program for female graduate students within her department to provide guidance on such topics as work-life balance, choosing mentors, and job search strategies in an attempt to keep these students in the scientific pipeline. Collectively, these endeavors have better prepared the next generation of scientists for careers in both an academic and non-academic setting.

 


Last Modified: 09/30/2015
Modified by: Lisa A Taneyhill

Image
